author: NHoogstad

title: EACHINE EF-01 30deg Camera Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a 30deg mount for the Eachine EF01. I was doing a 3" build and needed something, I decided to use the standoffs as my main anchor point. Surfacing is quick and dirty but it works. The camera is simply held in with hot glue however an elastic could also be used.


Designed for

This will work for the Eachine EF01 AIO VTx + Camera module without the case one.
I had an AIO unit off of a QX95 that also fit in this, but this file specifically has openings for the EF-01.

The frame specifically is the Liantian LT130 from Banggood. It's a good frame for the money. Note that I did need to cut a small slot in the top plate for the EF01 antenna to be able to sit back at 30deg.


Dimensions

  • Mount is at a 30deg angle.
  • Fits on 5mm OD standoffs
  • Fits on 25mm tall standoffs.


Quad Parts

If you're curious about the parts used in the images here are some helpful links.
Liantian-LT130 Frame
EMAX RS1306 4000kv motors
Racerstar RS20A 4-in-1 ESC
FrSky XM+ Rx


Was this helpful?

Tips are always appreciated if you liked the design and it worked well for you.

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: AM8 LCD Case Anet A8 Metal Frame Faceplate Remix

description.text:
This is a "remix" of the front LCD case for pheneeny's awesome Anet A8 All Metal Frame. If you haven't done it to yours, I highly, highly recommend it. It's well worth the cost and time it takes. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2263216

I wanted to add a cutout so I could more easily access the Y-axis belt tensioner. I also added some angles to the case itself. I was struggling trying to exit the original, so I ended up just taking measurements and making it from scratch. I also beefed up the screw posts on the inside because they didn't print well for me, maybe it was just my printer or settings, but they were very flimsy and one broke off instantly. I made them D-shaped and a little more solid.
I also got frustrated with the positioning of the buttons and eventually gave up and made the button holes much wider and made button caps (optional) to cover up the gaping holes. I'm not totally happy with the button caps, they work, but I will probably go back and make them look a little nicer at some point. The buttons just barely friction fit on top of the switch posts. It's loose enough they come right off, but they stay on without falling off. (At least on my printer. You may need to resize the button caps + or - 0.1% or more to your liking)

For me the LCD case printed as a perfect fit (after several revisions) I printed with PETG (unfortunately magenta, I ran out of red and I will have to get some more so it matches the rest of my printer!)
Not sure if anyone else has a use for this, but I figured I'd post it just in case someone else can't access the belt tensioner like me.

Printer:

Anet AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These settings worked for me, it's a pretty basic print and no supports or anything special really needed. It's all pretty thin, so I don't think infill will matter a whole lot. It's really up to you.

comments.text:
My LCD2004 dimensions are 16cm x 6.5cm x 20cm ( front of LCD scree - to back of pins.
I have tried three different version on Thingiverse - NONE are the correct size for me!
I have 2 Anet A8 - used both and different filaments - all three printouts were too small!
My machines are standard 8mm acrylic - I just want an LCD holder to use off the frame.... is this version the right size for me??
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: I am not sure, all I can say is this is about the exact size of the model from the All Metal Anet A8 kit. I did not technically remix that, but I used that file's dimensions as a basis.
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: Good idea, I had the same problem of the internal posts breaking off and the display button holes not being wide enough. Your part might solve this for me as well. Also the angle at the bottom is good, as my feet are different and the display frame nearly touches the table. Thanks for sharing.
comments.author: quasimodoberlin

comments.text: That's interesting, the screw posts printed really well on mine, what settings did you use?

The other parts I printed looked fine, but both on this part and the original part from pheneeny the circuit board spacers are weak. Here it is better though, because it did not break off and therefore is useable.

title: Brio compatible diesel engine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A brio compatible diesel engine

UPDATE 02/09/17

  • corrected position of holes in diesel_base (use v2)
  • increased diameter of pilot hole for furniture stud in brio_base_3ax (use v2)

Print the following:

  • 1x diesel base
  • 1x diesel body
  • 6x wheels (supports needed)
  • 1x diesel face
  • 1x brio base 3ax

I used the following to make the magnetic connectors:

  • 2x 12x3mm ring ferrite magnets with 3mm hole
  • 2x Silver upholstery nails 11mm diameter

For the wheel axles I used:

  • 3x 30x2mm metal rods

General notes

  • The face is rubbish; hopefully someone will remix a better one!
  • I used superglue on all joints and to stick the face on
  • I used acrylic to add detail to the face
  • I used a hammer to get the upholstery pins in

description.text: Removed the base of the horn that connects to a headband.

I created some USEFULL! things to improve my printer.
First of all LCD is angled. I dont need to lie on floor to setup printer etc.
Next I changed Z axis rods and bearings from 8mm to 10mm. Now, bed is very stable. Rod mounts are printed new, because original parts are very fragile and was cracked.
Last part is SD card cover to easy put card in to slot.

Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

I like the Design of the Crinkle Lamp by LoboCNC but after i printed it something seems to be missing. In the Remix Sektion were already some Base´ for the Lamp but i want to use some spare LED-Stripes .

So i fire up Fusion 360 and designed some new Base . Somewhat stylisher in my Opinion :D
With a 5mm Hole to put the cables out.

BEWARE: This Base is for a scaled down to 80% Lamp !!!!!!!!!!!!!

I designed 2 versions. the V2 has a tower to wrap a LED-Stripe around ;)
( i know it looks a bit crazy and could be mistaken for something different :D )

If you printed it please share a "make" or comment it

greetz

I'm building a 1/2 scale Bat Tumbler for my 6 year old. Basically a Power Wheels on steroids. It will be ran by 2 E Scooter motors. This will be a lengthy build as I am printing the entire interior. There will be more files uploaded as the project progresses.

I will be using this scale to check part fit and seam gaps so when I print out the full size one, it will all be perfect.

I used the really well done Recarro Seat by Gargi on Thinigverse. I designed everything else.

If you want to follow along with the build, visit my Facebook page "The Props Department".

Cheers!

title: iPhone 6 desk Mophie case + PowerBolt pad base

description.text:
I recently decided to get a wireless charging / battery case for my iPhone 6.
So I went with the Mophie juice pack wireless case. This --> https://goo.gl/8wjkym
I also got a 2nd pad. The Soundbot PowerBolt. This --> https://goo.gl/eEMnfv

So I designed a simple case around the PowerBolt and the case I have.
Hopefully you all like it if you're able to use it :)

It also works if you put a magnetic micro USB plug in the case! This --> https://goo.gl/8dihKU

Version 2 added to accommodate the new version of the charger.
(Space taken out where the microUSB cable goes)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I set the support overhang angle to ~50 degrees, so that it'd only be placed under where the cable goes.
If your slicer allows custom supports, that'd be the only place where it's needed.

description.text:
I wanted to beef up my collection of hexagon tiles to be used with MTG Arena of the Planeswalker (or with heroscape for the old schools out there). These pillars allow you to create multi level structures without the need to stack endless amounts of single hex tiles together. The Hex Pillar assembled is as tall as 6 hex tiles stacked on top of each other. The Tall Hex Pillar assembled is as tall as 8 hex tiles stacked on top of each other.

Be sure to check out my other hex pieces:
Locking Wood Floor: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2484959
Locking Stone Path: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2484754
Non-Locking (but still stackable) Stone Path: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1775936

Stay tuned for more sets to come...

Please let me know if you would like to see other hex tile sets!

title: Web Controlled Power Outlets - For 3D Printer Workspace

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0tXY_7EGgWU

This is a 3D printed, DIY, Web Controlled Power Outlet Box. Created to allow me to remotely power on/off my 3D printer, Lamp, Raspberry Pi, and CAD computer. Got tired of leaving everything on all day either before or after a new print. Allows full web control from my wired LAN and remotely over the internet.

Uses an arduino and ethernet shield to allow you to remotely control 4 standard 120v 5amp outlets using computer, tablet, or smartphone. 3D printed housing and cover that I custom designed and printed. Even has a little clear 3D printed cube that brings the lights from the Arduino to the front. Thought that was a bit cooler than just a power led on the front.

120V to 5V transformer from a scrapped phone charger. Custom made relay switched circuit board with NPN transistors. (Pre-made 4 Channel relay boards can be bought pretty cheap but I wanted to make mine). Pretty cool way to remotely control household electronics from any web enabled device.

All Files Attached Including:
.STL files, .INO Arduino Code, and index.htm (To be uploaded to micro SD and installed in ethersheild).

CR-10

No

No

.2

10%

title: Mini 100 Brushed Frame (8520 Motors)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Indestructible, light, flexible frame with camera and JST-connector mount. There is a hole on the floor to feed the receiver antenna through it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30

Notes:

After breaking many carbon-fiber frames, I decided to design my own to 3D-print it. I tested with different materials and designs (and spent many time transferring all the components from one frame to the next one) but decided to experiment with a flexible material to make it much more resistant against impacts.

I printed it with Flex-65 from Dutch Filaments (Head: 260°, Bed: 100° with skirt), which is rigid enough to fly without noticing any difference compared to a much stiffer frame but flexible enough to make it practically indestructible. I've crashed it many many times and you can almost always bend back or change a propeller and keep flying.

It also has some cutouts to insert a cable tie and so protect the components in case you land upside down.

Tips:

  • cut the motor cables longer that you'd need so you can easily change them without
    having to solder directly on the flight controller.
  • use Velcro to attach the battery to the bottom of the frame
  • use double sided tape to fix the flight controller and receiver to the frame

title: End Cap for unknown brand of sun shade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an end cap for sun shades / sun screen...

There are 2 parts one for the left and one for the right. Check the pictures if this cap will fit your extruded aluminium bar. (it might, because that part is most likely a half-product).

I got a second hand one, but the end caps were brittle due to the UV-licht.
(as you can see both of them were damaged)

Maybe you can use it :-)

Solidworks
  1. Scan the parts
  2. Use sketch tools to sketch picture
  3. measure the most importand distance (between the holes)
    Set the dimensions of the picture.
  4. Draw construction lines
  5. Draw sketch for extrusion
  6. Use smart dimension to figure out where to draw the hole that has broken off.
  7. Exit sketch and extrude the part.
  8. Add other features...

description.text:
Key Storage - Wall Mounted

Uses 4x 3mm screws to mount the 'Key_storage' to a wall/surface.
The screws can then be hidden using 4x printed 'Screw_Cover'.
The 'Key_Loops' can then be attached to a key ring and placed into the storage unit helping to keep your keys organized. If you want you can print the key loops in various colours to distinguish different sets of keys.

Please leave feedback if you attempt to print this design and upload some final photos.
Any tips are greatly appreciated and help to fund my studies in Product Design.

Thanks!

Needed a box to build an end of filament sensor for my printers, unfortunately, they don't seem to have a "pause printing" function on the Mightyboard, so I ended up taking the KW12-3 switches, put them in this box and hooked them up to a Raspberry Pi, which sends me a text message when the filament is running out... second best solution, but better than nothing.

The KW12-3 switch fits into this box, here's the link of them on ebay:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/KW12-3-10Pcs-Roller-Lever-Arm-Normally-Open-Close-Limit-Switch-Micro/172748661951?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

I also uploaded the program files I put together for a Raspberry Pi to get a text message on my phone in case the filament runs out. Leaves me a only few minutes to take care of it, but as my printer does not support a pause mode, this is the next best thing... Requires a 320x240 touch screen. After editing the config.ini file, it needs to be placed in the /boot/ directory.

print_settings.Notes:: If the bayonet fitting is too tight, you can sand the groove using sandpaper wrapped around a pen,  or you can use a small candle to rub some paraffin onto the tight areas.  You don't want to force a really tight fitting, because you run the risk of friction-welding the parts together and you won't get them apart again.

description.text:
The A4 rocket was developed by German scientists, including Werner Von Braun, during the 1930s and early 1940s. It was adapted for use as a weapon by the Nazis in WWII and renamed the V2. After the war it was used for research and helped pave the way for space programs in many countries.

This model is hollow with 1.2mm thick walls, allowing for two extrusion widths of .6mm. The Slic3r settings for some of the parts use an extrusion width of .63 to ensure good bonding between inner and outer walls. I used the Slic3r engine within Repetier for this project.

The entire rocket is 22" tall and 2.75" in diameter. The mid-section and fin sections are each about 7.6" tall. When printed at 100% scale, the fins fit within a print diameter of 6.2", just fitting within the print volume of an Orion Delta. Quarter-turn bayonet fittings connect most of the parts. The groove in the bayonet fittings includes a locking bump that will help lock the parts when turned 90 degrees. Index markers on the outside of the rocket help with alignment for assembly/disassembly.

Both the nose tip and nose cone base will bayonet-lock to the nose cone. The nose cone base then slip-fits into the mid-section. The jet-vanes assembly friction-fits into the tail of the rocket.

This model is mostly for display purposes, but I have added some features that should make it possible to use it as a flyable model rocket. The nose tip has a compartment for adding weight to position the center of gravity properly for stability. It is the same diameter as U.S. quarter coins, and will hold up to 136 grams in coins. The fin section has supports so a motor tube with 2.6" and 1.9" centering rings can be held in place when the mid-section is attached. Then, you would be able to swap motor mounts for 24mm or 29mm motors. You would need to file/cut four notches in the outer edge of the upper centering ring so it could be inserted past the four bayonet bumps.

The mid-section has an internal lug where a shock cord/static line could be attached. I have posted two versions of the mid-section, one with external 3/16" launch lugs and one version without.

I have included a verson of the nose tip that has the modified Wac Corporal second stage used in Project Bumper at White Sands and Cape Canaveral. It is just shy of 9" tall. I sloped the trailing edge of the fins of the Wac Corporal to make it printable without support. To make it truly scale, you would need to trim them to be perpendicular to the rocket body. http://www.wsmr-history.org/bumperaction1.htm

There is also a version of the mid section that has a simulation of the thin perforated section seen on many V2's. See Mid-ring.stl

If you build one of these to launch, please post photos and video of your rocket in action. I will seriously consider requests for modifications to the design that will help make it flyable.

Historical information and blueprints of the A4/V2 can be found here:
http://www.v2rocket.com/start/makeup/design.html

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

ORION Delta 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

See the Slic3r settings I have uploaded.

Copy the Slic3r settings files into the filament/print/printer folders at
C:Users > yourID > AppData > Roaming > Slic3r

If you are thinking of printing this rocket, the first thing you should do is use the Test Slice file to check your slicer settings. It allows you to quickly iterate through tests of the critical part of the fin section without having to commit to a long print. The entire fin section takes about 6 hours to print at 45mm/second, while the Test Slice only takes maybe 15 minutes to print enough for you to check the quality.

It is important to set the "Only Infill where needed" box to unchecked/OFF, even when infill is set to 0%. Infill extrusion width should be zero, also. This will eliminate a lot of tiny bits of plastic that Slic3r puts in the corners of fillets reducing z-banding on the outside surface caused by unneeded travel moves and retraction.

A 5% Archimedean chord infill setting provides reinforcing ribs in the fins to make them strong at a minimal weight penalty. I tried using the Cura slicer, but it does not have a fill-in pattern that is as good as Archimedean chords is for this purpose. Other patterns might add strength, but they also add weight. This rocket is stubby with small fins, so the lighter you keep the fin section, the less weight you will have to add to the nose for stability.

When you slice each part, you must place it in the orientation shown in the third photo to avoid the need for support material.

If you get the warning that the fin section is not manifold, you can ignore this and go ahead and slice it, at least with Slic3r.

When printed on the Orion Delta using MARS PLA, the fin section depends upon retraction to keep oozing and stringing to a minimum. But the frequent retractions can cause the hot-end to partially clog, resulting in under-extrusion on the cylindrical parts of the fin section while the hot-end is catching up.

I solved this by using the retraction setting that pushes .5mm extra filament after retract. The price you pay for this is some extra material at the ribs within the fins. This is mostly hidden anyway, but you may have to experiment with that value to prevent the ribs from showing through on the outside of the fins, especially if you have a different printer or use a different filament. If a few of the ribs poke through, and you are using PLA, it is usually easy enough to sand the outside of the fin down to make them smooth.

If the bayonet fitting is too tight, you can sand the groove using sandpaper wrapped around a pen, or you can use a small candle to rub some paraffin onto the tight areas. You don't want to force a really tight fitting, because you run the risk of friction-welding the parts together and you won't get them apart again.

comments.text: Finally, a nice model of the V2. And a flying one at that. Thank you. I was noticing that the curved parts are showing a fair bit of faceting instead of a smooth surface. Could you post .step (.stp) files?
comments.author: robertbl22

comments.text: Ok, I found how to create a mesh object with finer tessellation before exporting an .stl file.  Hopefully I can update the .stl files with smoother versions  tomorrow.   I'm still learnin'....
comments.author: robertbl22

comments.text: Thanks for posting the nose cone in .stp.  I opened it in Fusion360. The exterior looks perfectly smooth, but it treated the bottom of the cone as a flat surface instead of showing the internal geometry. I can see the outlines of the internal geometry. I think with a little work I could get in there and fix it.  BTW, Autodesk allows a free license to non-professional Makers under their education licensing. I tried FreeCAD and it was too buggy. I found Fusion360 to be vastly better. Exporting high resolution (high polygon count) STL meshes is very easy.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: Robert, I have uploaded a "Fin Section Hi-Res.stl".   Please take a look and see if it works OK for you.  In the meantime, I will do the same for the nose cone.  Having it output a mesh with surface deviation of .03 seems to smooth it considerably while only increasing the file size by about 25%.  I could go even finer,  but I think it is now below the threshold where you would notice the faceting on most 3D printers.
comments.author: robertbl22

comments.text: I was just about to make the leap to Fusion 360, but I have so much time invested in FreeCAD that I think I will continue trying to make it work, at least for a few more days.  When making a nose cone or tail cone with a spline curve, extruded 1.2mm and then rotated 360 degrees,  FreeCAD would introduce some weird tesselation artifacts (big dents) when the cone is fused with the fins.  I ended up making the fin section and nose using four 90-degree rotations of an extruded spline curve profile to avoid these artifacts.   But now converting this to a finer mesh causes issues with Slic3r at the boundaries of the four sections.   According to some tests I did today,  it looks like I just have to change those sections back to single 360-degree rotations to make generating a finer mesh possible and have it be slice-able with Slic3r.  The finer mesh settings seem to eliminate the original dent artifacts. Give me a couple of days to play this out, and hopefully I will have some smoother stl files to upload.
comments.author: robertbl22

comments.text: FreeCAD does not seem to want to smooth the surfaces no matter how I set tessellation.  I have uploaded the nose tip in .step format for you to work with.   If you have tools that can smooth it , ( I see that you mention Fusion 360 in your profile) I would like to hear about it.
comments.author: robertbl22

comments.text: Before I do that, let me see if I can get FreeCAD to output smoother .stl files.  I should be able to tweek the tesselation factor to reduce the bumpiness.  On the models shown,  after sanding to remove layer lines,  priming and painting, what remained of the faceting is barely noticeable.   If anything, I think it adds to the authenticity of the model, since most of the V2's you see in photos at museums have a lot of bumpiness because of the thin sheet metal skin.
comments.author: robertbl22

description.text:
The Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy.
Although not from my childhood, I do have fond memories of this show.

All parts are broken into colors. Using black, white, red, and silver/gray filament, no painting will be needed. You may need to color in the eyes, eyebrows, mouth, and the lines on the hands with a fine tipped permanent marker.

I built in supports on the hand. No other supports are needed. Brims may be needed for the arms and hands.

Finished model measures about 120 mm tall.

Nov. 25 2017: Added Grim Body Black v2. The original file may have caused an error in slicing.

description.text:
A support to use like a third hand that hold the soldering iron. Very useful to solder eletronic components together. A simple, must-have and pratical holder.

It already has a support material to print the first holder. At the end of the printing just break the support material at the slimmest line.

Second picture explain the use-exemple.

Alert!

Be alert of the security measures:

  • Make sure the support is fixed to the table before using it. It might slide and crash onto ground. It's wise to tape it to the table.
  • Don't put the support with the soldering iron on a place that you might bump. Also, make sure to place it away from child's or animal's reach.
  • Don't use it if you don't have experience with soldering.

title: Threaded Plugs for 5/8" and 7/8" Holes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a threaded plug and matching nut, for closing up a 5/8" hole in the wall of an enclosure or similar. We use these to plug up the hole we pre-drill in remote monitoring enclosures, to accept an optional/future external antenna that will utilize an N-female bulkhead. Although this bolt will plug a 5/8" (U.S. standard) hole, the bolt head (hex) is 22mm (metric) from flat-to-flat, because... I'm lazy and was already working in mm in my drawing. Anyway, we always use adjustable crescent wrenches to snug these down.

For water/weatherproofing, we typically add a buna/nitrile o-ring of size ID: 9/16", OD: 3/4", diameter 3/32". But any o-ring in/around those dimensions will work fine (for example ID: 5/8", diameter 1/16" is pretty common and will work).

EDIT: updated to have coarser threads that are much easier to print.
EDIT2: new v10 (STL file) that has a looser nut, mates much easier.

remixed_from.author: S±E
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2 Upgrade kit for E3D Titan Extruder

description.text:
The gentleman that originally designed this included the .stp file for these parts THANK YOU!

I have done the same: I have Autodesk Inventor 2018 as a student so I have included .ipt; .stl; and .stp.

My modifications are for an LM8LUU (8x15x45mm) for the top bearing and I moved the outermost zip-tie mounting holes 2.4 mm inwards (45.2mm bearing pocket).

I have also counterbored the screw holes as M3 is nearly impossible to find in that length by me. I have modified both for M3 and M4 since M4 is typically found in longer lengths locally, at least it is by me. I have also extended the 3 screw mounting points to give the titan extruder screws a bit more room.

I am not printing the M4 parts since I counterbored the screw holes to fit my M3 screws, just a bonus should someone not have M3 long enough to work.

I am printing on a Stratasys uPrint SE so you are pretty much on your own for print settings, 0.2-0.3 should be fine and I wouldn't print less than 30% unless using a stronger filament than ABS. M4 I might print 40% to avoid part failure, I don't believe 30% would fail....You don't want to print twice, walls might be a little thin.

Enjoy!

title: Meanwell SE-600-24 Encloser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I took SIERRA086's Meanwell SE-600-24 power supply enclosure and remixed it for a replacement power supply on my Lulzbot Taz 4/5. I picked this power supply up off eBay and didn't realize how under-powered the original power supply was until now!

If you choose to make one of these, you'll need (8) M3x8mm bolts and (8) M3 washers. Unfortunately, the holes don't line up perfectly, but they are close enough to melt just a bit with a soldering iron to perfectly align.

All in all, I am very pleased with how this turned out! Simple enclosure for a great power supply! As you can tell, I didn't make the cords modular - that just wasn't necessary to me.

The photo doesn't do it justice due to the crinkled plastic bag I placed the part in to keep from losing it.

As the original part was designed in 1964, it's out of patent and this digital representation is likewise unoriginal and in the public domain.

There's only one version at the moment, but I can adjust the sizing easily if you let me know what you need in the comments.

description.text: A simple storage box for holding up to five nozzles (M7). The base has three slightly greater than 6mm X 2mm holes. This is to accommodate the magnets to mount it to my printer (since the Wanhao has a steel frame). The hinge is printed in two pieces, and pinned with 1.75mm filament. To secure the pin you just melt the ends or glue it to the outside hinges.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

No

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The hinges print without needing supports. I printed at 0.1mm layers because the hole in the hinges didn't print completely round at a lower resolution.

Yet another nozzle caddy!

I needed a way to store my spare nozzles that was better than the little plastic bag they shipped in. I saw a number of solutions on here, but none of them were exactly what I wanted. So this is what I came up with!

It calls for a couple small pieces of 1.75mm filament for the hinge and three 2mm x 6mm magnets . The magnets should be snug (±0.1mm), but it wouldn't hurt to glue them in, depending on your printer's tolerances.

title: Fidget Locking Phone Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Design developed for Open Design Project, as a part of MAE 2250 course at Cornell University where it won the Outstanding Design Project award.

The challenge was to design a study aid based on user-needs interview with a student, and this is our findings:

The user has extensive, sometimes even excessive interaction with electronic devices, particularly the phone, and is often distracted by it. We decided to create a device that would reduce that distracting interaction. This will promote successful and worthwhile studying to ensure the student’s success in his/her final exams. The design we came up with is a phone case which can be locked with multiple mechanisms, and has a fidgeting “toy” to help direct the user away from the device inside.

Use 1.75mm filament as hinge pins, and glue the flange/gear pins onto the case. 9X 8mm M3 socket cap screws and 1X 2.5mm hex key are needed for assembly. 2.5mm hex key also acts as the key to the lock.

Fits Iphone 6 Plus, turn key CW to lock, CCW to unlock.

description.text:
This is a stand for displaying belt buckles and medals. It is meant to be free standing, doesn't need to be attached to anything to be used. It will fit multiple sizes of buckles or medals while not covering any detail making it great for use in a display case. It is also meant to hold the buckles or medals fairly vertical for easy viewing. It was also designed to not use a lot of material when printing or take up space which can be at a premium in a display cabinet. Overall size is approximately 2.5" wide, 1.6" deep, and 2" tall. It does used raised feet to eliminate warping issues while printing, and to be able to be used on surfaces that aren't perfectly smooth. Like my other models, it is also small printer friendly due to its small size.

For reference, the buckle shown in the photos is 4 inches in diameter with the main plate 0.15" thick, while the medal shown is 2.75" in diameter and .22" thick.

When printing, supports are required for the bottom surface only the top overhang is designed to not need supports while printing. Should be printed vertically, NOT horizontally as shown in the model view.

description.text:
These are a set of front and rear sights that will mount on the standard Nerf accessory rail. The original design was a great set of sights by RayvenLover. I changed it to make the front sight longer, enhance it to better suit printing the dots in a different color, and added a friction nib to the bottom of the sight to prevent the sight from moving. I had to remove a separator between the rail sections on my Nerf gun to be able to slide the front sight all the way from the back to the front on my Hammershot. You likely will not be able to clip the sight over the rail without breaking it.

To achieve the bright dots on the black background, use a filament change script to allow you to change the filament from black for the sight main body to a more visible color for the dot such as white, yellow, or orange. Place the model on the print bed with the dot facing up so that it is the last thing that is printed. Once you slice the model at the resolution you like, determine the first layer where the dot is isolated and have the filament change there.

The script I used to change the filament for my Prusa MK2S came from this page
https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/simplify3d/topic:10525

Prusa

remixed_from.author: K-rnix
remixed_from.title: Filament Guide for Tronxy Prusa All Metal (Two Ways)

title: Prusa i3Mk2S Filament Guide for Side Feed

description.text:
Take your kilo of filament off of the Z-frame of your Prusa i3Mk2S and set it on the table next to your printer. It makes it easier to change filament, and it has improved the quality of my prints.

This is the second version of this thing. I updated the clips so that the print head clears when moving towards +X at or near the +Z limit. I also thinned out the clips and put holes in them all over the place, which is merely cosmetic. The other important change was to straighten out the feed path by raising the center wheel and making the bracket separate so it can be rotated down.

There is some strain on the filament as you approach +Z max and +X max. I am not sure that it will print well there. But it is great everywhere else. My prints are typically pretty short in height, and I have not had any problems!

The final part is pretty flexible. Not an issue for usability, but the clips will definitely break if you whack them.

UPDATE - I separated the TUSH Remix²
www.thingiverse.com/thing:2538819

I no longer use this myself. This is what I use now:
www.thingiverse.com/thing:2536629

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

See Notes!

Infill:

See Notes!

Notes:

File | Layer Height | Fill Pct | Fill Type | Raft | Juice | Support | Qty
BearingStandOffCounterBored | 0.1 | 100 | Conc | Y | N | N | 6
Half_Wheel | 0.1 | 100 | Rect | N | N | N | 6
SingleWheelFrameClip | 0.2 | 100 | Rect | N | Y | Y | 1
FrameClipForTwoWheels | 0.2 | 100 | Rect | N | Y | Y | 1
TwoWheelBracket | 0.2 | 100 | Rect | N | N| N | 1

*Juice - Use ABS juice to keep the part from pulling up while printing.

These parts work well in ABS, I did tweak the dimensions that surround the frame a bit from the original Shii diemnsions for the clip. I had printed that in PLA with the original dimensions. Keep that in mind if printing in PLA, it may be a bit loose.

File | Post Processing
BearingStandOffCounterBored | Drill out 3mm holes
bearing_cover | clean up with hobby knife for a snug fit
Half_Wheel | clean up with hobby knife for a snug fit
SingleWheelFrameClip | Drill out 3mm holes, remove support, cut out spacer
FrameClipForTwoWheels | Drill out 3mm holes, remove support, cut out spacer
TwoWheelBracket | Drill out 3mm holes

A razor saw works best to cut out the spacers. They are actually separate parts in the prints, but they are only 0.25 mm from the bracket so they will end up being Siamese-ed together in the print.

Thingiverse is a dangerous place. I have wanted to take my spool off of the Z-Frame for a long time. Changing the filament was not as easy as I would like, and I was always worried about dropping a kilo spool of filament on the bed. You can see that I change filament a lot. Each part, except for the 6 bearing stand offs are different colors. The standoffs are all black, but the other 15 parts are 15 other colors. Note that this is not just for fun (but it was fun!), having the face of the half_wheel that is on the same side as the control panel is useful, because you can see that the filament is threaded in the wheel correctly.

Browsing Thingiverse one day, I found the TUSH and I thought that would be an awesome way to upgrade my printer, but I needed something for filament management to get up over the Z axis screw and rod. I found the Tronxy filament guide and that made me think that together they would be awesome! But the Tronxy is not for the Prusa i3MK2S. It has good parts though, so I hacked off the bearing support and added it to the Shii filament guide that I was already using. The Shii filament guide had served me well, but it would pop loose, so I extended the front leg and closed the bottom so it completely surrounds the Z Frame. I added a spacer block at the top that the screw goes through so you can open the clip to install it, and the spacer keeps from squashing the upper portion when you tighten the screw. I also added a lot of holes for fun! I then duplicated that clip and a simple bracket for a third filament guide wheel.

Part | Quantity| Notes
608 Bearings | 3 | Can be any, but good ones are better. I used Dragon brand "Speed" model
3mmX20mm FHSC, stainless | 1 | Socket flat head is optional, as is stainless, but you only live once.
3mmX16mm FHSC, stainless | 4 |
3mm nylock nut, stainless | 5 | Nylock are optional. Regular flat nuts work as well.
Be careful when tightening the screws in the clips, too tight and you will split the clips.

comments.text: Nice! Have yo used my wheels from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2461969 ? You need three wheels to keep the filament in place when the printer head moves back and forth.
comments.author: K-rnix

comments.text:
@ K-Mix. Yep, those are your wheels! And you can't see them, but the inner bearing supports are yours too, but now they are separate pieces to serve as bushings for the m3 screws.
Yes, my original plan was to use the 3 wheels to keep the filament from popping out when the head translated in the x-direction during the print. In practice I find that is not actually necessary. I am updating this, and it is a work in progress. I am running the modified unit on my printer now.
I now have a single wheel on the right side above the right z-axis motor. The hexagonal stand plugs in to the hex hole in the right upper z-rod support. I have found that that works well, and it is a lot less complicated. It also solved the issue where the filament kinked up near the z-axis limit.
comments.author: K-rnix

comments.text: It is indeed the most natural location and filament path but why so many pulleys, why such complexity ?????
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: You are right, there are a lot of parts. You could probably do without the center wheel (yellow in the picture) but it ensures that the filament stays down inside the left (red) and right (blue) wheels to prevent feed issues. I find that when the head moves it can pull about 1/8th of a turn out the spool at a time. That is enough slack for the filament to hop out of the wheels, and then it could get tangled up and fail to feed properly.

description.text: Another mksa remix for your pleasure. Removed the slit along the top. Replaced it with a hole for a 1/8th inch diameter bolt to push the laser down. Added fillets so you can just push the laser button and slide it into the tube. That will keep it on instead of a rubber band. Take any magnet you want and put it in the base. remixed_from.author: bekroogle
remixed_from.title: Yet Another Wanhao Duplicator Spool Holder

description.text:
I got a used printer that was missing one of the spool holders. Rather than spend $20 on one from another country I decided to print one.

I was having trouble with the nut, so I added one at 101% and one at 102% diameter.

Additionally I provided 2 other lengths (90mm, 60mm and original 80mm from stop to middle)

Printed at 0.3mm course resolution because who cares, it's in back. Decided to use 4 shells with 10% infill.

The other thing I did was import the stl's to sketchup and fix the mesh problems that sketchup has problems with. My reason was to be able to make it shorter and longer, however after I printed the first one I decided it didn't really matter.

It worked, but my dog managed to eat it when I removed it (she eats ABS for whatever reason). And now I've donated the printer to a school, so I don't have photos of the actual printed part! Sorry.

This is an adjustable arrow or tube cutting jig.

I banged one of these together when I needed to cut some arrows a little while ago and found that I kept using it to make nice square cuts in other sorts of tube. It wasn't very adjustable, so i thought it was worth having a proper go. Seems to have worked out alright.

If you want to get a very clean cut, the trick is to cut the arrow lightly and rotate it as you move it toward the blade.

You can adjust the SCAD files to suit different grinder or rail profiles, or if you're really struggling let me know.

The spacer was actually pretty useful. I got the profiles close on the grinder mounts (one had to be built up with a little tape), but they didn't sit flush on a surface. I was trying to think of how to shim them to the same level then I realised that I had a machine that could build the exact shim I was after. duh!

I can't see myself making another one of these, but if I were to, the things I'd do differently are:

  1. Slot for the standoff should have been wide enough for an M6 bolt (and knob), but I just made a mistake here so I've had to use some screws that were lying around. When I have to adjust it to allow for blade wear, I'll have to use a screw-driver. I've updated the SCAD and STL that I've uploaded, so they should be ok.
  2. I'd probably use a heavier rail. the 1mm aluminium is quite flimsy. I might add a couple of extra stand-offs to stiffen it up.
  3. After I put it together, I couldn't come up with an easy way to check that the blade was vertical. I'd probably try to include some way of doing this (maybe I should print a jig!)

This solved my ongoing broken heater bed wire problem.
Mounts under heater bed to acrylic sled using M3 bolt and nut.
Harness, sheathing, or just a bunch of wires are placed in the semicircular cutout in the block and secured with a small cable tie
I'm not a designer by any means, so it is what it is unless you care to improve upon it.

description.text: This is a surface mount for a Yi Home camera. I secured this using a 3M automotive trim tape. title: Betyár - Hungaryball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Say hi to Betyár, the second Hungaryball in my countryball series. Betyárs who were usually very skilled horsemen were the outlaws and highwaymen of the 18th and 19th century Hungary. Several of them have become legendary figures who in the public mind fought for social justice. Their curly mustache and typical hat are still an important part of the Hungarian folklore.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This model is designed to be printed in multiple parts, WITHOUT support. Since the eyes are separate pieces you can print the tree layers in the colors of your country's flag. For the best accuracy print it slow! I've used 20 mm/s for the outer walls. Print two of the clips.

Assembly

The model is designd to be assembled without glue only with its snap-fit joints, just like my other countryball. First attach the tree layers and the hat with the clips, then push the eyes with the contours in their place and attach the mustache.

Note that the tolerances were designed to fit the accuracy of my Ultimaker 2. You will need a similarly accurate printer and fine settings for the snap-fit joints to work properly, otherwise you might have to readjust the size of the clips.

The is an Edited file of the Original Prusa i3 MK2s from the one and only Joseph Prusa. All credit goes to him for the original file.

description.text:
Hi

Recently i've start being active in Twitter.

Some of my tweets are small OpenSCAD figures using less than 140 characters.

I printed 3 of them and i decided to share.

I have much fun writting creative code that fits in a tweet. I encourage to all the OpenSCAD programmers to try and share their own tweets.

The Code

Copy-Paste this code in OpenSCAD, try and tweak to get your own versions.

Fractal Pyramid:
f(90);module f(w){cylinder(w,w,w,$fn=4);if(w>2){for(i=[0:3])rotate([0,0,i*90])translate([w,0,0])f(w/2);translate([0,0,w])f(w/2);}}

Dragon Egg
for(i=[0:360]) rotate([0,i*0.25,i*137.5]) translate([2*sqrt(i),0,0]) rotate([0,i*0.15+30,0]) cylinder((i%7==0)?i/25:2,4,0.5);

Vase / Planter
$fn=99;linear_extrude(height=9,twist=90,scale=2)polygon([for(i=[0:359])let(r=5+sin(i*6))[r*sin(i),r*cos(i)]]);

And of course...Have fun!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 it's ok

Notes:

Rotate the Egg 180º and add a Brim to have a good bed adhesion.

Use 'vasemode' for the vase (see belowhow to do it in Cura)

title: Sign Posts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
'Sign Posts' can be used in all sorts of fun and practical ways....

  • Fun messages
  • Not so subtle hints...
  • Instructions
  • Messages
  • Directions (for house guests etc.)
  • Table place cards (for events)
  • Whatever else you can imagine!

Easy to print, easy to assemble and custom configurable. Apart from 3D printing the necessary parts all you need to do is make up your signs to insert. These look great printed on a laser / inkjet printer but can also be hand written.

Making up you signs is easy as well (refer to the images for sizes). Print out your signs, as shown in the template image, cut out, fold in half then insert into your sign holder... easy as that.

Your own unique custom signs on demand!

The parts included are:

Base - to keep your sign post standing

Posts - three lengths are provided (50 / 75 / 100mm)... use shorter if you plan to have lots of signs on top.

Signs - to insert your signs (printed on paper or card) into. Three lengths are provided (40 / 50 / 60mm)

Spacer - use if you want to add space in between signs. Helps if you want multiple signs pointing in the same direction.

Cap - seals off the top of your Sign Post for a finished look.

Please refer to the images and instructions provided for additional information (particularly around support removal). And, because there are "endless" possibilities for these signs... post images showing them in use. Have fun with them...

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% or more infill recommended

Notes:

Do not select any support as the necessary support has been designed in. Well sliced files printed on a precise / accurate machines should result in support that will snap away relatively easily (usually by hand).

Raft is recommended to ensure good build plate adhesion due to the minimal contact surfaces of some parts.

Please refer to the images for additional information.

Assembly is quick and easy...

Firstly remove the designed in support (Refer to the images for additional information). Well sliced files printed on a precise / accurate machine should result in support that can be snapped away by hand. However, if your support is slightly fused using a craft knife gently should clear it away fairly easily.

Next check all the intersecting parts are clean of any imperfections so they will slide together snugly. Using a light silicone spray will help with slicing the parts in / out (as dry layered PLA can cause resistance between parts).

Final assembly time...

Make up the signs (names / messages / instructions) you want to use and insert them into your signs(Refer to the images provided). Then just assemble everything... fit the pole to the base, add a sign set to a first angle (octagonal positioning), add another sign set to the next angle required etc. etc. Lastly, fit the cap to top your 'Sign Post' off.

Easy to do, useful... and fun!

I considered making a joiner however the hole runs right through (which increases strength due to internal and external shells) the centre of each pole so a simple joiner wouldn't work, it would fall through / inside. This is part of the reason I included the spacer part. For example, you could start with the base, add a spacer, add a 100mm pole, add another spacer then start adding signs....

title: Anet a8 rear-frame stabilizer\ cable holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this stabilizer to minimize the strain on the frame after i installed the HULK bracing.
As intended it does also make the rear acrylic Plates way more rigid .
I also had a crack in my frame that i had to fix with an acrylic plate and glue, this rod helps keeping that in place as well.

If you build this Do NOT over tighten the nuts on the rod as this may crack the frame, Its only intended to stabilize the two acrylic plates and not change alignment.

You will need:
6x M8 nuts(i used two nylock 1 in each outer cap and 4 normal on the inner counter knobs.
1xM8 threaded rod cut to 34cm

You will get:
2x outer knobs
2x inner knobs
2x 25mm spacers for 6mm frame
2x 25mm spacers for 8mm frame (to fill in the holes in the anet frame)

Before assembly take a 9mm drill-bit and run trough the holes in the two inner knobs so that you don`t have to suffer so much when threading it into place .

Preheat all the nuts on your heatbed together with the Knobs for an easy installation .
You can cover the rod in tape or that plastic cable wrap that came with the printer for a better look .
If you are sure you are going to leave it on permanently you may as well put on heat shrink although this is very tricky.

If you struggle fitting the spacers you can always preheat them in a cup of hot water then they should slide right in

title: Basic Knife sheath for a custom knife (knife included)

description.text:
Made a quick sheath for a custom knife.
Thought i'd share the files to show my approach.

  1. trace the blade on paper and scan it
  2. load the image in SketchUp and size it so it matches the actual size of the blade
  3. trace the image
  4. create a box and lid around the blade, mainly using the offset and extrusion tools.
  5. print the two parts out and glue them together with superglue

comments.text: Design suggestion, I'm still using this design and it's one of my favorites. I'm still battling with the fan shroud melting from the heater block and while I'm going to attempt correcting it myself with my meager skills in sketchup but a fairly easy fix may exist. The problem I think myself and others are seeing is because the heat block is set so close to the X axis it leaves little room for the fan duct to go in-between the bearing block and the heater block. If the part named bowden mount (the one with the radial fan offset on the left) if it was a few mm further away from the bearing block but the hole for the fan was left the original distance from the X axis it could create a few mm of heat break for the fan ducting.

comments.text: I started making an adapter to add on to this carriage that allowed for a cable chain and am 90% there. I found something out in the test fitting process though, at least with the 2 bearing model. The addition of a cable chain looks like it may introduce some X axis drag and thus cause the printer head to move with the resistance from the chain. There is some flex on the X plane using the 2 bearing model and I stopped development myself because of this. I may switch to a 3 bearing design to overcome this though and continue with it. What I'm finding this morning is like some others below is that the print fan has melted from the block heat in the back. I need to see how to overcome this or it may be a deal killer.

title: TEVO Little Monster Above Extruder Cable Support

description.text:
Adds support for the wiring umbilical mounted on the extruder motor bracket with the 3D printed bolt. Directs the umbilical between X and Z columns out of the way from anything it can catch on.

Does the same for the filament PTFE tube above the extruder to prevent the filament from catching on the springs on the belts holding up the extruder. For best results the PTFE tube should rise above the topmost spring.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height, 0.4 mm nozzle

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed mine with ABS to make the support less brittle and allow for the snap fit clamping for holding the wiring harness and filament PTFE tube.

Mounting Instructions

Mount the support into the hole of the triangular extruder motor mounting bracket using the printed bolt.

The umbilical arm should be directed between the X & Z columns, this will put the filament supporting arm above the extruder filament intake. Both the umbilical and filament PTFE tube snap into their respective holders and can be easily removed if needed.

I am new to 3D printing and find Fusion 360 to be the easiest to use when taking an idea to a working model.

I use parameterized dimensions to allow easy tweaking, like reducing the height for faster test prints.

Took a bit of experimentation to get the clamps right and figure out how to design 3D printable threads.

author: vsch

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with PLA

description.text:
A very effective dust shoe for Ø65 routers similar to Makita RT0700 series and Katsu 101748.
Since these routers are air cooled and blows air towards the work piece, dust will be spread all around the workshop. This dust shoe has been made with air reflectors (the two pipes on the side) to lead the air to one side.
Vacuum hose connection: 41mm (OD), 35mm (ID)

The dust shoe was made by Norwegian Creators (https://www.norwegiancreations.com/2014/08/an-open-source-cnc-dust-shoe/) and I have done the following changes:

  • splitted the dust shoe in two so that it is possible to change tool without removing the whole dust shoe.
  • made "pockets" for 5mmx3mm magnets
  • rounded off some of the corners on the bottom part so that skirt can more easily follow its contours.
  • also included some branding on top.

The following hardware is needed:

  • M3 bolt, 25mm and nut
  • 8 off 5mmx3mm magnets (strong type)
  • Material for skirt
  • Glue

Creative Commons License
Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

title: High air flow CNC PSU cover parts

description.text:
This is a revision of the CNC Power supply stl files produced by febtop Tech.

Some users noted that the original covers didn't have any air flow on the open sides of the PSU so this is a redesign to allow more air flow through.

Whilst no known reports of failed PSU's have yet surfaced and air flow requirements aren't quite known this version should be considered preventative of any potential issues that overheating might cause.

There are 2 options for the lid, one is flat the other has little 4mm feet on the bottom for people who are intending to stand their PSU on the lid side this will allow air to flow in through the bottom.

If you're looking for the original febtop versions you can find them here: https://github.com/febtop/STL-files

author: Plasto

title: Dys Elf frames and extras for 3d printing and cnc routing

description.text:
This is my repository of current frame and canopy experiments with the Dys Elf 83mm micro quadcopter.

FRAMES :
To fit 2" props on the Dys Elf, I think the 98mm CF frame is the best bet, but 95 will probably just squeeze them in. 98mm should allow the stock motors to fit without extending motor wires. A lot of frames are untested, but should be pretty close to useable. Give them a try! The deeper ones are intended for 3d printing, and the flat ones are for cnc routing out of carbon fibre.

CANOPIES :
I've been experimenting with Miu Miu Cheong from the Dys Elf owners group on FB to get a micro swift mounted to his elf. The 2mm enclosed canopy will work as a top plate if you use standoffs for the fc and plate, but it's close to 10g. The lighter one with just side plates may be a better bet. The CF top and side plates is my favourite, but we haven't made it yet. More news soon...

My intention with these is to try and get the most out of this little quad performance-wise and make it easier to repair and work on because the stock parts are a bit of an interdependent jigsaw puzzle!

The Led discs work pretty well, but you need to trim the sides of the leds to make them fit. The led itself fits inside the little lip so it can't fall out. You will need 3mm longer screws to make them work!

Enjoy!

Richard

title: Airsoft Arduino Bomb Replica - Kajaki Airsoft

description.text:
Hello, everyone!

First of all: English is not my native language. And second: This is a work in progress thing. This took me a lot of hard work and time to do so I would really appreciate seeing likes and makes of you guys :3

I'm Connor, that's my usual nickname and Airsoft Callsign, I'm a member of an Airsoft Burgos group called "Kajaki Airsoft". I've been playing Airsoft for mostly a year now and, a few months ago, I don't remember how, but I ended up investing weeks in programming, making the first prototype of the Airsoft bomb Arduino replica. The objective, of course, was to make our Airsoft matches more enjoyable.

So I started with a code by yinbot: https://github.com/yinbot/Airsoft-BombPro I modified it to add more functionalities and to make it work for my design.

This is a brief resume of the features of the replica:

· 3 game modes:

-Search and Destroy: If you played Counter strike before you know how its works, one team plant the bomb and protect it, the other team mission is to defuse it.

-Sabotage: It's like Search and Destry but in this mode, you can plant and defuse the bomb as many times as you can until the time is gone

-Domination: In this mode, two teams, green and red, fight to control the bomb under the name of their team, The team with more time in control win.It's our favorite mode.

·R/G Dynamic Lights: The RGB strips are connected to the Arduino giving information to the players about the current state of the match.

·Sound: It makes different beeps depending on whats happening.

·Build-In Battery: It uses an Airsoft battery that can be recharged without taking it off the bomb.

Video: https://youtu.be/-KVgdE7JmYE

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 / 0.2

Infill:

25% / 100%

Notes:

If you use high resolution to print this thing, it's probable that the pieces can't fit on it
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-KVgdE7JmYE" ></iframe>

Arduino

This part is simple, I have added to this thing a .rar file with all the information of the project, including de code that you only have to upload to an Arduino ONE board. And then connect it with the pieces following this diagram.

The battery can perfectly be a 9V, but the bomb is designed for Tamiya connectors (The most used airsoft connector).

First prototype

So, I took the code of the previous one and modified it to fit in the new design, and then I designed the shell based on the pieces I have hanging around the house.
